title: Air Monitoring Reports: What OSHA Requires
summary: A practical guide to OSHA-relevant air monitoring report elements, data integrity controls, and defensibility.

sections.heading: What Must Be Included in an Air Monitoring Report
body: Identify core report elements for defensible air monitoring documentation.
Explain data fields needed for field-to-report traceability.
Describe standardized formatting practices that reduce review delays.

sections.heading: Sampling and Calibration Data Integrity
body: Explain sampling and calibration data quality controls.
Describe validation steps before report generation.
Show how structured workflows reduce transcription and omission errors.

sections.heading: Exceedance Documentation
body: Describe how exceedances should be captured and communicated.
Explain why contextual evidence matters for defensibility.
Show how to align exceedance records with reporting workflows.

sections.heading: Review and Sign-Off Workflows
body: Outline reviewer sign-off and QA responsibilities.
Describe versioning and change controls for reporting.
Provide a repeatable workflow for publication-ready outputs.

faqs.question: Which report elements are essential for defensibility?
faqs.answer: Sampling details, calibration records, contextual conditions, threshold interpretation, and review sign-off are core elements.

faqs.question: How do teams reduce report rework?
faqs.answer: Use structured data capture and standardized reporting workflows tied to validated source records.
